Award.AwardTitle: Preparation of Data Driven Mathematical Scientists for the Workforce

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at East Tennessee State University (ETSU) provides three years of support for three cohorts of ten students each. Students major in the Mathematical Sciences with a Concentration in Computational/Applied Mathematics, or Statistics; or receive a minor in the mathematical sciences, with a big data focus, as they complete their major requirements in one of eight STEM departments. Students enter the program as sophomores. The program starts with a two week summer session in which students are immersed in computational science, both theoretical and applied. In the Fall, and for the next three years, students attend a bi-weekly seminar that alternates between mini-workshops, visiting speakers, career planning, team building, and a variety of other activities. Students are expected to graduate after three years of support.

The technical merit of the project lies in its alignment with the interests of students who aspire to work in a computational, high-technology environment. The summer program provides a concentrated Mathematical Modeling and Computational environment that prepares participants for the next three years of study. As such it represents a well-tested method of initiating a long-term training effort when participants enter with diverse educational backgrounds. The overall three-year effort intends to develop students into mathematical scientists who solve complex data-driven problems. Additionally, the project integrates with other programs at the institution - supported both by NSF and other organizations, to enhance the impact of these particular scholarship initiatives. Other collaborating programs include NSF-REU, NSF-UBM, NSF-Noyce, TBR-Access and Diversity Initiative, and the ETSU Governor's School. Recruitment of women and minorities is facilitated due to cooperation and communication with other STEM education programs currently in operation at East Tennessee State University. The project's activities, e.g. seminars, speakers, internships, and courses, enable students to benefit from long-term immersion in a culture of predictive modeling; analysis of large and complex or fluid dynamics data sets; and scientific computation, all of which hold promise to increase retention of students through graduation.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM program housed at East Tennessee State University during 2014 -- 2020 made a substantial impact in regional undergraduate STEM education.This scholarship program provided pivotal means to improve recruitment, retention, and graduation in STEM, while fostering 21st century digital building block skills.

Female Underrepresentation in STEM. Longitudinal enrollment in the S-STEM program had several academic terms when the participants divided almost evenly by gender. However, from total head counts there were nearly one third female versus two thirdmale scholars. Most of the participants were recruited from Mathematics (which has almost an even split by gender)and Computing (with less than 20% females).

Completed Bachelor's Degrees. The average four-year graduation rateat East Tennessee State University is 26%, i.e., nearly one-in-four studentscompletes a Bachelor's degree over four years. The four-year graduate rate of S-STEM scholars ranges between 67% and 91%, reflecting the positive impact provide by the workforce preparation scope of this program.

Continuation of Graduate Studies. Several S-STEM participants have continued graduate studies either in Master's degree programs (4 students) or doctoral programs (6 students).

Micro-credentials Resemblance.  Several S-STEM scholars completed a version of the Mathematics minor that resembled micro-credential training on modeling with upper-lever coursework that included: Statistical Machine Learning;Stochastic Modeling; Numerical Linear Algebra; Statistical Modeling; Mathematical Modeling.nThroughout five academic years, from Fall 2013 through Spring 2018, S-STEM scholarships induced a relative percentage increase in the Mathematics minorenrollment equal to 37%.

Full-Time Employment Upon Graduation. S-STEM scholars were successful landing employment in positions requiring skills with an interplay between data, computer simulations, and mathematics or statistics. Some of the employers in the private sector and federal government include: Clayton Homes; Eastman Chemical Company; National Security Agency;Riparian LLC; U.S. Army Materiel Systems Analysis Activity.


Last Modified: 08/04/2020
Modified by: Ariel Cintron-Arias
